docs.lead_paragraph: REMEMBER the frightening things that were going to happen if the Clinton health care plan passed? Like losing the right to choose a doctor or a health plan? How about the slow death of old-fashioned medical insurance and the like-it-or-not march into health maintenance organizations? Not to mention restricted benefits and even rationing. Harry and Louise, the fortysomething couple created by the Health Insurance Association of America, vented their anxieties about these possibilities -- and, by extension, millions of other Americans' fears, too -- in a series of television commercials in 1993-94, fretting around the kitchen table as health care legislation was furiously debated, and ultimately killed, on Capitol Hill. Now, with the benefit of three years' hindsight, it can be said: Harry and Louise were at least half right. There were indeed big changes in their future.

headline.main: Harry and Louise Were Right, Sort Of

docs.abstract: Proportion of American workers in managed health care plans has grown to 74 percent from 55 percent in 1992, when Pres Clinton was beginning his first campaign for health care reform, according to recent survey of employers by KPMG Peat Marwick; health care experts say people believed that if Clinton plan died, managed care revolution would die with it; say days of fee-for-service medicine, covered by traditional indemnity insurance, have clearly passed for most Americans; drawings (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: I EXPECTED a mass exodus of the crossing guards,'' Gary Iacobacci said, shaking his head in amazement. ''I thought they'd pack it in. But it just didn't happen. Most of them are still out there.'' Mr. Iacobacci, a six-term councilman in Bloomfield, was referring to the town's decision to hold down property taxes by eliminating health-insurance coverage this year for 37 school crossing guards. He voted against the resolution to eliminate the benefits. While the guards may still be there, he soon won't. On Nov. 5, after a campaign characterized by tax protests, he was defeated for re-election.

headline.main: The Human Face of a Budget Cut

docs.section_name: Health; Education; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: AFTER AT&T began offering acupuncture to its management employees as an option in one of its health insurance plans in January, the company said ''less than a handful'' of workers sought treatment. Kaiser Permanente, the nation's largest H.M.O., had more success, saying it had strong demand at its clinics in California that offered acupuncture and other alternative medical services. Alternative medicine, long on the fringes of medical care, is slowly being offered by more health plans. While most states require health insurers to cover chiropractic care, some states have gone further, requiring many insurers to cover treatments like acupuncture and naturopathy.

headline.main: Now in the H.M.O.: Yoga Teachers and Naturopaths

docs.abstract: Alternative medicine, long on the fringes of medical care, is slowly being offered by more health plans; for example, Oxford Health Plans, Norwalk, Conn, recently took alternative medicine beyond state mandates, announcing that it would become first large medical insurer to have network of alternative-care providers; although medical community has increasingly incorporated some forms of alternative medicine in traditional treatments, doctors caution that many forms of alternative care are still being tested and question whether Oxford's action is too much too soon; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN August, a Tennesseean who had been fishing in the Amazon Basin returned home and died of yellow fever. His death was the first confirmed yellow fever death in the United States since the 1920's, according to Dr. Robert B. Craven, the head of the yellow fever-spotted fever section of the Federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Fort Collins, Colo. According to Dr. Craven, the tourist had been planning to get a vaccination, but discovered he had to drive 50 miles to an authorized agency for it, and decided against it.
docs.abstract: Practical Traveler column on information about what vaccinations may be required or advised for certain destinations (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: SPURRED partly by last summer's Olympics spectacle and partly by a national push to revamp public housing, this city is razing two dilapidated, low-income projects that have long been a public embarrassment and replacing them with new housing. The Atlanta Housing Authority, in a partnership with private developers, is using tax incentives, Federal grants and the more flexible guidelines that now govern public housing to build a mixed-income neighborhood in place of two of its projects, Techwood Homes and Clark Howell Homes, which are being demolished. The site is next to some of Atlanta's most valuable commercial property.

headline.main: A New Mixed-Income Village for Downtown Atlanta

docs.abstract: Atlanta, Georgia, spurred partly by last summer's Olympics spectacle and partly by national push to revamp public housing, is razing two dilapidated, low-income projects that have long been a public embarrassment and replacing them with new housing; Atlanta Housing Authority will build mixed-income neighborhood in place of two of its projects, Techwood Homes and Clark Howell Homes, which are being demolished; photo; map (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has chosen Rosa M. Gil, a senior vice president of the Health and Hospitals Corporation, as the new chairwoman of the agency, which runs the city's public hospitals and clinics, according to several people who have been briefed by City Hall. Dr. Gil, who is currently in charge of Lincoln Hospital, Metropolitan Hospital and two diagnostic centers that the corporation runs in the Bronx, will replace Maria K. Mitchell, who announced this week that she was leaving her $133,000-a-year post to pursue a more lucrative career in the private sector. The appointment is expected to be announced today.

headline.main: Giuliani Is Said to Choose Chief for Hospital Agency

docs.abstract: Mayor Rudolph W Giuliani has chosen Rosa M Gil, senior vice president of Health and Hospitals Corp, as new chairwoman of agency, according to informed sources; Gil, who is currently in charge of Lincoln and Metropolitan Hospitals, will replace Maria K Mitchell, who recently announced that she is leaving $133,000-a-year post (M)
